result.title: Week 1
result.content:
Hello everyone!

On the first day we learned how to create variables with some basic data types (int, string, bool, double, char), how to input them from the user , and how to display them on the console screen. We didn't have enough time to go through loops, arrays, and strings so don't worry we'll go through them first thing next time and for now you can try to understand them alone or just skip them.

For reference, please refer to the following codes:

1.Declaring and i/o integers: http://ideone.com/Udh0pf

2.Declaring and i/o doubles : http://ideone.com/1tFupv

3.Declaring and i/o boolean : http://ideone.com/qlWE1I

4.Declaring and i/o strings: http://ideone.com/S5ps7q

5.Declaring and i/o characters : http://ideone.com/VPOX8A

If you want to code at home, you can either use ideone.com , or download visual studio.

On ideone, you will not get a console that will output and input everything in order, you must write all input beforehand, so i recommend downloading visual studio.

To create a project in visual studio, look at this under prequisites for reference: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms235629.aspx

Also we will soon be solving problems that you might see in competition, so everyone please make sure to stick around a little bit more and i assure you things will get more interesting and fun.

I just wanted everyone to get an understanding of generally how a full program works and what we need to create a detailed program like this (if statements, for loops ). It is okay if you didn't understand it or any of the above.

There is no need to know any coding beforehand, if you play around with the following codes and create your own programs, everything will become extremely simple.

Learn to enjoy the error messages. Usually the error message will tell you the line number of the error, or give some sort of description on whats wrong.

Coding is very sensitive and the computer is extremely dumb, any sort of spelling error and the computer wont recognize what you are doing.

“Anyone who has never made a mistake has never tried anything new.” ― Albert Einstein
